sentences.english: The other two members of the committee are just featherweight .
sentences.chinese: 委員會的其他兩個成員只是無足輕重的人。

sentences.english: Here's just some lame extra footy.
sentences.chinese: 這裏的只是一些跛腳的額外無足輕重。

sentences.english: He just laughed, and dismissed the question as unimportant.
sentences.chinese: 他只是笑了笑，認爲問題無足輕重而不予考慮。

sentences.english: When this book first came out, critics called her a lightweight.
sentences.chinese: 當她出版了第一本書時評論家們說她無足輕重。

sentences.english: No longer the lightest word of a man made her head dizzy.
sentences.chinese: 她不再會被男人一句無足輕重的話弄得頭腦發昏。

sentences.english: I said it didn't matter that I wasn't doing much.
sentences.chinese: 我曾說我做的多不多無足輕重。

sentences.english: Flowers are irrelevant to a dog. So their scent is meaningless.
sentences.chinese: 花對狗來講無足輕重，所以花香對狗無關緊要。

sentences.english: When he texts Mrs B, the content is unimportant.
sentences.chinese: 他跟B女士的短信內容無足輕重。

sentences.english: The categorization of English verbs as strong and weak is getting less importance in the modern English.
sentences.chinese: 對英語動詞強弱的分類在現代英語中正變得無足輕重。

sentences.english: It's a snotty takedown of a straw man.
sentences.chinese: 這完全是是一個無足輕重的人的下賤的貶低。

sentences.english: This man says Mr. Gul's visit is of no importance.
sentences.chinese: 一名男子說，居爾的訪問無足輕重。

sentences.english: Do you think Lal will care for anything so unimportant?
sentences.chinese: 你認爲拉爾會看上如此無足輕重的區區之物嗎？

sentences.english: One who quibbles over trivia . Much of our research is wasted on trivia .
sentences.chinese: 我們的許多研究都浪費在一些無足輕重的瑣事上。

sentences.english: None of that matters a whit, and none of it will make you happier.
sentences.chinese: 這些根本無足輕重，也無一會使你更快樂。

sentences.english: Our social interactions on the other side of the door had little weight inside the house.
sentences.chinese: 在這扇門內，我們在家門外的交往往往顯得無足輕重。

sentences.english: They feel they have become disempowered by recent events.
sentences.chinese: 他們感到因最近發生的事件他們已變得無足輕重了。

definition: lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
to bury oneself in work (idiom); to be engrossed in work/to make an all-out effort/up to the neck in work
plethora of things to tackle/multitude of loose ends/very complicated/chaotic
to be a tax on (one's mind)/to bother/to trouble/to be concerned
to be reluctant to give up a post
to think for oneself and act accordingly (idiom); to act on one's own initiative
properly/satisfactorily/firmly/very fitting/appropriate/proper/to be in good order/also written 妥帖
separated in life and death/to part for ever
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
